text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events. A group of prominent individuals, around the Columbian Liberty Bell which was one of the major features of the Decoration Day Parade of May 30, 1894. This was cast under the auspices of several patriotic societies, mainly the D.A.R. and was patterned after the famous Liberty Bell of 1776; the money being raised by the patriotic individual Wm. O. McDowell. This stood at the base of the Worth Monument which, tho not seen, is at the right. The buildings in the background are on the west side of Broadway, between W. 24th and 25th Streets, tho the photographer is on Fifth Avenue and views westward.
A reproduction of this picture appears on page 698, of Vo. 15, of the Illustrated American on June 16, 1894.

The Illustrated American

May 30, 1894.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Decoration Day Parade.

text:
Parades, Celebrations and Municipal Events: The 1894 Decoration Day Parade marching south on Fifth Avenue past the reviewing stand at Madison Square. The photographer is viewing westward towards the Broadway side of this intersection and shows buildings at the S.W. and N.W. corners of W. 24th Street which are respectively the Fifth Avenue and the Albemarle Hotels. Other photos of this parade appeared on page 698 of the June 16, 1894 of the Illustrated American.

May 30, 1894.

The Illustrated American
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Decoration Day Parade.

text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Dewey Arch at Fifth Avenue and 24th Street as viewed northward up the Avenue. The Broadway street car tracks are in the foreground and this thoroughfare is at the left. Madison Square Park is on the right.

Copyright 1899
J. S. Johnston
Gift of Urbrock Collection

1898
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Dewey Arch.

text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Dewey Arch at Fifth Avenue and 24th Street, viewed northeastward towards Madison Square Park. In the foreground are the Broadway street-car tracks.

Copyright 1899
J. S. Johnston
Gift of Urbrock Collection
1898
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Dewey Arch.

text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Dewey Arch at Fifth Avenue and 24th Street, viewed northward up the Avenue. To the right is Madison Square Park.

Copyright 1899
J. S. Johnston
Gift of Urbrock Collection
1898
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Dewey Arch.

text: Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The Dewey Arch erected on Fifth Avenue at E. 24th Street. This photograph is eastward towards the building line at Madison Avenue. Appearing there is the Madison Square Presbyterian Church (erected 1854) surrounded by the ever growing Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. At the right margin is the old Hotel Bartholdi at the S. E. corner of 23rd Street and Broadway. 1898.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - The Dewey Arch.

text:
Dewey Arch and Colonnade, Fifth Avenue at 24th Street. At the extreme right is the Fifth Avenue Hotel (1859-1908). In the centre, to the left of the policeman, is what appears to be an early type of horseless carriage.

1899.

Ewing Galloway.

Dewey Arch of Triumph, erected at Fifth Avenue, Broadway, and 24th Street, to commemorate the victory of Admiral Dewey at Manilla Bay, during the Spanish-American War.
Fifth Avenue Hotel is at the extreme left.

1899.

The Dewey Arch on Fifth Ave., at 24th Street. This view shows the side of the arch that faced northward, and is different in ornamentation from the reverse side. It also being the side observed by the marchers as the parade passed southward thru same. The Hotel Bartholdi (S.W. corner of Broadway at East 23rd Street), appears thru the span.
September 1899
George S. Barlow Collection.
Gift of George D. China.

Crowds at 10:00 A. M. awaiting the Dewey Parade, with the reviewing stand, and the Dewey Arch and Colonnade in the background, Fifth Avenue at 24th Street. At the right is the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and above it, in the order named, are the Albemarle, the Hoffman House, and the St. James Building.
September 30, 1899.
View No. 1

Ewing Galloway.

Fifth Avenue, Broadway, and 24th Street at Madison Square, showing Dewey Triumphal Arch and Colonnade. 1899.
August Loeffler, Photographer,
from P.L. Sperr, collection.

The Dewey Parade passing under the temporary wooden arch and col- onnade erected for the victory celebration, Fifth Avenue at 24th Street. The picture also shows the east side of Broadway north from 24th Street. At the right, the Brunswick Hotel may be seen over the tree tops of Madison Square Park, and above the Brunswick is the Waldorf Astoria.

September 30, 1899.
View No. 2.

Ewing Galloway.

Fifth Avenue and Broadway, north from W. 24th Street. These two thoroughfares cross each other at 23rd Street and all buildings fronting on this open area acquire Fifth Avenue numbers, though technically they are on Broadway. North of 25th Street (above the Worth Monument) Broadway resumes its identity. Buildings on the right, face on to the normal building line of Fifth Avenue and extend from 25th to 26th Street. At the left is the Albemarle Hotel, adjoining the 2 larger units of the famous Hoffman House.

Brown Brothers

1907

Fifth Avenue south from 24th Street, showing at the right a close view of the famous old Fifth Avenue Hotel just before its demolition. From its beginning in 1859 this hotel was closely connected with New York history, and to a lesser degree national history. Now, with the competition of the new Waldorf-Astoria at 33rd Street, evil days have fallen on the Fifth Avenue, and soon it will be nothing but a memory, with the Fifth Avenue Building replacing it.

1908.

Brown Brothers.

Fifth Avenue, west side, south from 24th Street. At the right is the Fifth Avenue Building, which replaced the famous Fifth Avenue Hotel, and which it resembles, except in height. In the centre is the Fuller, or Flatiron Building, whose fabulous height of 21 stories made it one of the sights of New York in other days. On the left is the statue of Admiral Farragut by the great American sculptor, Augustus St. Gaudens. About 1924.

Ewing Galloway.

North on Fifth Avenue and Broadway from 24th Street, Madison Square.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway, Photographers.

P.L. Sperr collection
